name: Bunyakovsky conjecture
summary: The Bunyakovsky conjecture is a proposal in number theory that states a polynomial with integer coefficients will produce infinitely many prime numbers if it meets three conditions: the leading coefficient is positive, the polynomial is irreducible over the rationals, and there is no common factor greater than 1 for all values of the polynomial as the input varies. In simpler terms, the conjecture is a generalization of Dirichlet's theorem on arithmetic progressions to polynomials of higher degree.
head: \(f(x)\) is a non-constant polynomial with integer coefficients that satisfies the following three conditions: The leading coefficient of \(f(x)\) is positive.\(f(x)\) is irreducible over the integers (it cannot be factored into two non-constant polynomials with integer coefficients).The values \(f(n)\) for positive integers \(n\) have no common prime factor greater than 1 (equivalently, the greatest common divisor of all values \(f(n)\) for \(n\in \mathbb{Z}^{+}\) is 1).
